topics.body:
"@Thanotos Omega":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/552547076368727c1eda2b00#post_552547076368727c1eda2b00
On the plus side more and more police officers are having to wear cameras; even though there's instances of police officers turning off their cameras on duty that's instant grounds for a firing.  An example of this was that a couple months ago a police officer beat the shit out of a unarmed individual and before he did so, keep in mind that the person was handcuffed, he walked up to his dashcam and the dumbass said "we're red; give me a second to turn this off"; he got fired instantly for destruction of evidence and while that is barely a punishment it does give the bad apples food for thought of they either have to behave well or get fired for destruction of evidence.

Good thing about police cameras is that they either have to:
A)Behave good on camera
B)If they turn off their camera that's instant grounds to get fired because that's destruction of evidence.


While that doesn't fix the problem it does keep these individuals out of the police force cause if you're a police officer that gets fired for destruction of evidence you're not going to get hired as a police officer again.

topics.body:
I just thought of something.  Maybe the reason why humanoid robots haven't caught on is lack of empathy with them and they either fall into either not human looking enough or falling into the uncanny valley.

What I mean by this is that look at this robot:
!http://images.sodahead.com/polls/001568019/robot-39634456767_xlarge.png!
What is wrong with it?  It's too realistic.

Maybe instead people should be focusing on idealistic robots rather than realism.  If robots that are meant to look humanoid instead focused on idealism then people would be more responsive to them?
